docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Can riding a bicycle lead to erectile dysfunction or impotence? JULIE WALSH YES It is well established that cycling can cause penile numbness, erectile dysfunction and impotency. At Boston University, several studies have shown a significant correlation between cycling and these conditions. In one study, 4 percent of young, healthy male cyclists in their 20's and 30's reported erectile dysfunction compared with only 1 percent of runners of the same age, fitness level, and health status. Although this is a small percentage, the data suggest a statistically significant increase in problems compared to runners.

headline.main: A Link Between Bicycles and Impotence?

docs.abstract: Question of whether bicyle riding can lead to erectile dysfunction or impotence is argued by Dr Irwin Goldstein, who believes it can, and Dr Ira Sharlip, who believes benefits of riding a bike far outweigh any risk of sexual dysfunction (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: My wife and I had barely settled down across from each another when she got the bad news: she had smallpox. An inauspicious start, I thought, trying to tamp down any sense of satisfaction. This became easier to do once I got my own diagnosis: spotted fever. Things weren't looking so hot for me, either.

headline.main: Putting Health at Risk Just for the Fun of It

docs.abstract: Infection, board game developed by Dan Sullivan, pits contestants against one another on a playing field run rampant with disease; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at the University of Missouri wanted to test the theory that the way to make better, shorter business meetings was to take the chairs away. And sure enough, comparing outcomes for 111 meetings, they found that those conducted while the participants were seated lasted longer than meetings in which the participants remained standing. However, the quality of decision-making was the same for both formats. The study, which appears in the current issue of The Journal of Applied Psychology, looked at 56 standing meetings and 55 sitting meetings for five-member groups of students ages 19 to 44.

headline.main: The All-Rise Method for Faster Meetings

docs.abstract: University of Missouri researchers, comparing outcomes of 111 meetings, find that those conducted while participants are seated last longer than those in which participants remaing standing and that quality of decision-making is same for both formats (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Members of an expert committee of scientists that assessed the safety of silicone breast implants formally issued their report today, calling for more research on risks of rupture and other local complications that can arise from the devices. Although there is no scientific evidence pointing to silicone implants as the cause of major diseases, the scientists said, women who have breast implants, whether they are filled with silicone or salt water, have the right to know what the chances are that the devices will slip or deflate or lead to infections or scarring.

headline.main: Panel Calls for Study of Some Implant Risks

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a common reaction: fear of the dentist's drill. Now scientists say the feeling is not only real, but they can show just what happens in the brain to cause it. Reporting in the current issue of the journal Science, Dr. Alexander Ploghaus and colleagues at Britain's Oxford University and in Canada said they hoped their findings could lead to better ways to treat chronic pain. They did brain scans of people who were expecting pain and found that a certain area was activated, which may help prove a theory that the fear of pain is worse than the pain itself. ''One knows the situation where one clings to the dentist chair in anticipation of pain and probably because of that finds the pain subsequently gets more intense than if they relaxed,'' Dr. Ploghaus said in a telephone interview. His team recruited 12 volunteers who agreed to be strapped to a machine that would nearly burn their hands, deliver a warm feeling or do nothing at all. Each painful pulse was preceded by a light of one color, warmth by another color and nothing by yet a third color. The volunteers quickly learned to associate a certain color light with pain. ''We measured brain activity throughout the experiment,'' Dr. Ploghaus said. The researchers used functional magnetic resonance imaging, which measured which brain cells were activated by detecting how much oxygen was used. Although there was some variation by individuals, for the most part one part of the brain lighted up in anticipation of the painful burn and another lighted up when the burn itself was delivered. ''Expectation of pain activated sites within the medial frontal lobe, insular cortex and cerebellum distinct from, but close to, locations mediating pain experience itself,'' Dr. Ploghaus's team wrote. ''The area that has been involved in anticipation of pain is an area that is believed to be involved in 'gut feeling' decision,'' Dr. Ploghaus said. Previous experiments have shown that people often realize something unconsciously before they realize it consciously, and a certain part of the brain is activated. This could be involved in pain response, too. ''I think we are seeing here some autonomic conditioning,'' Dr. Ploghaus said, ''the typical changes that you see when you have to run away from a threat.'' Dr. Ploghaus, who experimented on himself before subjecting volunteers, said the heat was bad enough to be distressing but not enough to cause a burn. ''I felt quite threatened when I saw the light preceding the pain,'' he said. He hopes to use this research to help people with chronic pain. Recent studies suggest that the fear of pain is much worse than the pain itself for such patients. Patients will, for example, contort their bodies to avoid pain, thus causing even more. ''We want to screen drugs and psychotherapy for their ability to reduce the anticipation activation,'' Dr. Ploghaus said. ''If that activity is abolished, that shows us these treatments can be effective in reducing pain in chronic pain patients.'' The theory would explain why narcotics, antidepressants and antianxiolytics work for pain. None address the pain itself but rather make the patient less anxious about it.

headline.main: Fear of Pain May Be Worse Than Pain Itself

docs.abstract: Dr Alexander Ploghaus and colleagues at Britain's Oxford University and in Canada study peoples' fear of pain; say they hope their findings can lead to better ways to treat chronic pain; researchers do brain scans of people who were expecting pain and find that certain area is involved, which may help prove theory that fear of pain is worse than pain itself (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the early 1970's, Dr. James Stevenson, then a graduate student in psychology at Stanford University, developed a theory about why he had so much trouble sleeping. Dr. Stevenson, who had been blind from birth, suffered insomnia at night, and in the daytime experienced ''sleep attacks,'' which arrived one hour later each day, playing havoc with his efforts to get to classes on time.

headline.main: Melatonin Used to Restore Sleep Patterns in Blind People

docs.abstract: Researchers at Oregon Health Sciences University find that daily dose of hormone melatonin cal help restore sleep patterns in blind people; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The worst part of sickle cell disease is the numbing, painful episodes that can strike any time, searing the body with waves of agony as cells in crucial organs, starved for oxygen and nutrients by blocked blood vessels, wither and die. Doctors and patients can do little but endure until a crisis has run its course. Powerful pain-killing drugs can help, as can blood transfusions. But, basically, it is something to be tolerated until it subsides.

headline.main: Drugs May Ease Sickle Cell Crises

docs.abstract: CytRx Corp and Cypros Pharmaceutical Corp are separately developing drugs for sickle cell disease that they say may be able to decrease duration of its numbing, painful episodes, reduce length of hospital stays and lessen need for strong pain killers; doctors at Harvard Medical School are also conducting trial to see if breathing nitric oxide gas during a crisis will shorten the event and reduce formation of sickle blood cells; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The worst part of sickle cell disease is the numbing, painful episodes that can strike any time, searing the body with waves of agony as cells in crucial organs, starved for oxygen and nutrients by blocked blood vessels, wither and die.    Doctors...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans, famous for wanting their cake and eating it too, were delighted to learn that even though French foods seem to be rich in fat, much of it artery-clogging saturated animal fat, the French are not nearly as likely to be cut down in midlife by heart attacks. This intriguing phenomenon is called the French Paradox, and it has drawn comment, criticism and speculation for much of this decade. But the latest treatise on the subject, published in a recent issue of The British Medical Journal, suggests the paradox may not be so paradoxical after all. Rather, the authors maintain, it is only a matter of time before the fatty French diet exacts its coronary toll. These scientists, Malcolm Law and Nicholas Wald, specialists in preventive medicine at St. Bartholomew's and the Royal London School of Medicine and Dentistry, point out that for decades until 1970, the French ate much less animal fat and had significantly lower blood cholesterol levels than did Britons, who were in no better shape than Americans.

headline.main: Paradox or Not, Cholesterol in France Is on the Rise

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on report by two British scientists that it is only a time lag, not a so-called French Paradox, that accounts for fact that the French are not nearly as likely as Americans or Britons to be cut down in midlife by heart attacks despite having a diet rich in saturated animal fats; Malcolm Law and Nicholas Wald note that until 1970, the French ate much less animal fat and had significantly lower blood cholesterol levels than Britons, who were in no better shape than Americans; other scientists still say Americans would be wise to emulate the French in consuming more wine, fiber, nuts and other heart-friendly nutrients and in eating less; cartoon; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Americans, famous for wanting their cake and eating it too, were delighted to learn that even though French foods seem to be rich in fat, much of it artery-clogging saturated animal fat, the French are not nearly as likely to be cut down in midlife...

docs.lead_paragraph: Fewer people are drowning in the United States, and two reasons may be a decline in alcohol use and a rise in sedentary behavior among young people, researchers have reported. The number of people who drowned declined to 3,959 in 1996, from 5,700 in 1986, said the researchers, Dr. Gordon Smith of the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health in Baltimore and Dr. Jonathan Howland of the Boston University School of Public Health, both injury experts.
docs.abstract: Researchers report that fewer people are drowning in United States, and two reasons may be a decline in alcohol use and a rise in sedentary behavior among young people (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Thies Marshall, director of the U.S.A. Gymnastics Athlete Wellness Program, is one of a growing number of educators, coaches, researchers, physicians and parents who are concerned about the female athlete triad, a syndrome experts have defined as three distinct but related problems: disordered eating, suspended menstrual cycle and premature bone loss. Ms. Marshall understands the syndrome, which can lead to permanent damage, better than many. She lived it.
docs.abstract: Growing number of educators, coaches, researchers, physicians and parents are concerned about female athlete triad, syndrome experts have defined as three distinct but related problems: disordered eating, suspended menstrual cycles and premature bone loss; Nancy Thies Marshall, now 42, recalls that she suffered from these disorders in 1972 as youngest member of United States women's Olympics gymnastics team; photos (M)
